text: well one of the surprising things to me
when i started learning about clinical
genetics
was that almost all genetics is risk
genetics you know i had the idea that if
you had a mutation it was going to cause
a disease and there was nothing you
could do about it and so i think i share
that perception with a lot of the the
public that it's very deterministic and
it turns out that it is not even in
those cases where you've got a very
dominant mutation that's running through
a family it can affect people at
different points in their life at
different ages and to different
severities so every gene is really a
risk gene and we're always talking about
risk and that was a big surprise to me
now i think what's happening with with
is that there's a huge over expectation
of what genomics can tell us about our
health and that's gradually going to be
corrected over time in society partly
because of education and and research
and partly because people will go ahead
and get their genomic information and as
i've heard from a lot of them they'll
say what what is this all you know
is this what is this all i've got
and they'll also
have to understand a little bit more
about statistics we talked about that
ahead of time and and they're going to
have to understand that wow a 40 percent
increase risk that sounds pretty scary
but if your increase in risk goes from
one percent to less than two percent
that really doesn't mean very much and
that's where we are with a lot of these
things that are available today
your risk of heart disease goes from 1.2
percent to 1.6 percent
and that's a that's a significant
percentage but it's really still a very
small risk so i think that we've got to
understand a little bit more about
statistics and we've got a sort of
reality tester sanity test the uh
genetic information that's coming at us
um can you talk a little bit about the
apoe4 gene what that means to people and
and what your experience was sir well
james watson when he got his genome said
he wanted to learn everything about it
except for one thing there's a gene
which gives you a feeling for your risk
for alzheimer's disease if you have one
copy of it you're at about three times
the risk of getting alzheimer's disease
if you have two copies of it you're at
about 10 or 15 times the risk so that's
a substantial risk marker and
alzheimer's disease is common so it
really means something in the world
so as a paradigm for this whole issue we
took the issue of disclosing alts apoe
for alzheimer's disease to people and to
ask the question is it going to terrify
them are they going to get a
catastrophic reaction and what are they
going to do with the information
and just to sort of encapsulate 10 years
of research and three now going on four
randomized clinical trials into a couple
of sentences you could be on television
are you offering me a job
uh
is is that they in in the situation that
we used which was controlled screening
people for distress beforehand
counseling them after if they wanted no
one had a catastrophic reaction number
two there were surprises they changed
some of their behavior they took they
took vitamins they did more exercise
number three they actually bought more
long-term care insurance this was the
first study to show that people with a
genetic marker would actually change
their insurance purchasing habits
and number four
there's a self-protection
uh mechanism so we we just finished a
paper called i know what you told me but
this is what i believe
and it turns out that even though they
walked into our medical center and we
said with all authority well this is
your risk people sort of said you know
what i think i know what my risk is and
so they just there was almost an
anchoring effect and they didn't change
that much so we've discovered a lot of
things about what it means to receive
genetic results that i hope will become
applicable from one gene really to all
of them
francis is the alzheimer's situation
something that we can learn lessons for
in terms of other other discoveries that
are out there oh i think so i think it
is and bob's work is really laid out
in the real world how this can be
received in a way we can learn a lot
from as as we talked about as we get
better and better at identifying the
hereditary contributions to long lists
of diseases so that they're as good at
making predictions as we are now for
alzheimer's that whole question is going
to get raised and if you're thinking
about would you want the test or not it
seems to me there are three things that
you're going to want to know about that
test is what kind of risk is it able to
provide you with
we talked about one well you know here's
a test that can tell you your risk is
elevated by 40 but if it was one percent
to begin with yeah
but if on the other hand it's
alzheimer's disease which we know is
common and it might elevate your risk by
15 fold well that's a big one that you
might want to pay attention to so that's
one factor how much risk can this test
actually provide you second what's the
burden of the disease
if it's cancer well you're probably
pretty interested in knowing about that
because we do have a sense that cancer
is a bad disease and there are often
things you can do about it if you're at
high risk
but if it's you know wet ear wax
you can test for that by the way
not maybe quite as driven to get that
information
and then the third factor is is there an
intervention alzheimer's no
so maybe even though the risk is high
and the burden is high
the intervention's not there you might
multiply those things together and still
get i don't want to go there but if it's
brca1 and the risk could be very high
because you've got a strong family
history the burden is very high and the
intervention could be life-saving then
your interest goes up
